Legal_Issue: Whether the Refugee Appeal Division (RAD) erred in its standard of review, analysis of new evidence, and credibility assessment
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), SC 2001, c 27
Evidence_Assessment: New evidence was reviewed but excluded as irrelevant or untimely
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to establish refugee status
Credibility_Factor: Inconsistencies in the applicant's testimony led to negative credibility findings
Legal_Rule: The RAD must apply reasonableness unless specific legal errors are identified
Procedural_Issue: Analysis of new evidence and procedural fairness in appeal process
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed based on credibility concerns
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: RAD properly assessed procedural fairness in handling new evidence
Legal_Framework: IRPA framework for refugee claims and appeals
Applicant_Challenge: Challenged RAD's standard of review, credibility assessment, and exclusion of new evidence
Defendant_Response: RAD upheld RPD's decision based on credibility and procedural grounds
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Alleged persecution based on political opinion
Outcome_of_Review: No error found in RAD's decision
Governing_Rule: Reasonableness standard applies to RAD decisions unless legal error is shown
